docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal advisory commission that will study the future of Medicare kicked off a year of work today with members declaring a desire for bipartisan agreement but skirmishing over President Clinton's proposal to open the program to millions of people 55 to 64 years old. One member, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, former chief economic adviser to Mr. Clinton, cited new data from the Congressional Budget Office to show that his proposal would not increase the Federal deficit or harm the Medicare trust fund.

headline.main: Study Panel On Medicare Begins Work, In Conflict

docs.abstract: Federal advisory commission on future of Medicare, 17-member panel that includes 10 members of Congress, begins work; members cite desire for bipartisan accord but skirmish over Pres Clinton's bid to open program to people 55 to 64 years old; panel member Laura D'Andrea Tyson cites new Congressional Budget Office data to show proposal would not increase Federal deficit or harm Medicare trust fund (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Medical Examiner of New York concluded yesterday that the death of a patient in a West Side medical clinic after recent cosmetic surgery was the result of complications from general anesthesia.. The patient, Joel Cunningham, 33, of Jersey City, died on Jan. 8 shortly after a liposuction operation that was performed by a person who, prosecutors say, was not a licensed physician.

headline.main: Report Links a Death at Plastic Surgery Clinic to Anesthesia

docs.abstract: New York Medical Examiner finds Joel Cunningham, 33, who died at LaFontaine-Rish Medical Associates clinic, New York City, after liposuction operation performed by person who was not licensed physician died of complications from general anesthesia; clinic's director, Sonia LaFontaine, is free on bail in mail fraud case involving scheme to perform unlicensed cosmetic surgery at clinic and bill insurance companies for procedures; her husband, Arthur Kissel, who faces same charge, has not be arrested; her lawyer says two licensed doctors performed surgery (M)
docs.snippet: The Medical Examiner of New York concluded yesterday that the death of a patient in a West Side medical clinic after recent cosmetic surgery was the result of complications from general anesthesia..     The patient, Joel Cunningham, 33, of Jersey...

docs.lead_paragraph: A little more than a week ago, the State of Oregon took the historic step of deciding that it would pay to help dying poor people kill themselves. The state's Health Services Commission voted, 10 to 1, to include doctor-assisted suicide on the list of ''treatments'' covered for Medicaid patients. It joined doctor-assisted suicide to other forms of ''comfort care'' for any ''terminal illness, regardless of diagnosis.'' The commission did not march into this medical and ethical minefield unaware. Oregonians voted to legalize doctor-assisted suicide by a narrow margin in 1994, and then reaffirmed that vote by a solid 60 percent to 40 percent last November. Neither vote dealt with public financing, however. Dr. Alan Bates, who heads the commission, said in a telephone interview yesterday that ''with that large a minority on such an issue, whether the state should stay out of it was certainly part of our discussion.''
docs.abstract: Oregon's decision to fund doctor-assisted suicide under Medicaid as form of 'comfort care' for terminally ill challenges assumption of government neutrality on issue (M)
docs.snippet: A little more than a week ago, the State of Oregon took the historic step of deciding that it would pay to help dying poor people kill themselves.  The state's Health Services Commission voted, 10 to 1, to include doctor-assisted suicide on the list...

docs.lead_paragraph: The winds that blow across Premium Standard Farms' long barns here carry the stench from hundreds of thousands of confined hogs for miles over the northern Missouri hills, enraging many neighbors. ''The odor is here almost on a daily basis,'' said Larry Guffey, who has a yard full of chickens himself, but objects to the overpowering smell from the hog barns.

headline.main: Pollution by Factory Farms Inspires Industrial Approach to Regulation

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration proposes far-reaching strategy for protecting waterways from manure pollution through tighter regulations than agriculture has ever faced; at heart of plan is that factory-like farms should be governed by Environmental Protection Agency rules resembling the strict pollution limits typically set for industry rather than the more forgiving standards long applied to farms; pollution created by nation's largest pork producer, Premium Standard Farms in Princeton, Mo, discussed; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Unico American Corporation said yesterday that it was in preliminary talks to merge with another company. The announcement sent Unico's shares up $2.50, to $17.50. Unico, a Woodland Hills, Calif., insurance company, is up 33 percent this week and 67 percent in the last 12 months. No information was provided about the prospective partner, and Unico said ''significant issues'' must be resolved before any deal was struck. Unico sells property, casualty, life and health insurance, and it makes loans to cover premium payments.

headline.main: UNICO AMERICAN SAYS IT IS IN TALKS ABOUT A MERGER

docs.abstract: Unico American Corp says it is in preliminary talks to merge with another company (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study by the American Association of Retired Persons says that elderly people spend nearly one-fifth of their income on medical care and prescription drugs, even though most have Medicare and some type of private health insurance as well. The study, issued today, said that poor Medicare beneficiaries who do not qualify for Medicaid -- about two million people -- spend half of their income on health care, on average.

headline.main: Study Issued In Bid to Halt Medicare Cut

docs.abstract: American Association of Retired Persons says that elderly people spend nearly one-fifth of their income on medical care and prescription drugs, even though most have Medicare and some type of private health insurance as well (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Michael H. had not had a shave or haircut in months when he was found one recent morning sleeping on the floor of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in suburban Lancaster, next to empty cans of tuna and soup from the church pantry. There was little to suggest that he had once been a prosperous college graduate with a wife and two children -- until he developed schizophrenia, lost his job and, without insurance, could no longer afford the drugs needed to control his mental illness.

headline.main: ASYLUMS BEHIND BARS: A special report.; Prisons Replace Hospitals for the Nation's Mentally Ill

docs.abstract: Fox Butterfield, in special report Asylums Behind Bars, says Los Angeles County Jail, by default, is nation's largest mental institution; it holds 1,500 to 1,700 inmates who are severely mentally ill, most of them detained on minor charges; situation in jail, criticized as unconstitutional by Justice Dept, is most visible evidence that jails and prisons have become nation's new mental hospitals; almost 200,000 people are behind bars on any day; more than 1 in 10 of total are known to suffer from schizophrenia, manic depression or major depression; rate is four times that in general population; there is evidence, particularly with juveniles, that numbers in jail are growing; what experts call criminalization of mentally ill has grown as issue as nation's inmate population has exploded and as corrections officials and families of emotionally disturbed have become alarmed by problems posed by having mentally ill behind bars; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is early morning on a recent Tuesday, and Gary Parr is hard at work. Since arriving four hours earlier at his 35th-floor office overlooking Times Square, Mr. Parr, the co-head of Morgan Stanley's global mergers-and-acquisitions group, has dispatched a banker to Asia to counsel a client on a corporate restructuring, weighed in on a bid for an insurance company and mapped out a London trip to meet a chief executive who wants to sell the company he runs. Four floors down, the activity is just as frenzied. Two of Mr. Parr's associates, Derek Kirkland and Douglas L. Brown, are huddling in Mr. Brown's office, poring over a list of insurance companies Morgan is advising. Within 30 minutes, they have doled out eight assignments to 20 Morgan bankers, including missions to Asia, Europe and Latin America as well as New York.

headline.main: There's a Steady Rush To the Corporate Altar; Mergers and Acquisitions Continue At a Record Pace Across-the-Board

docs.abstract: Corporate mergers and acquisitions continue at record pace across-the-board; Securities Data Co says so far this year, financial services industry--including banks, investment firms and insurance companies--is leading mergers pack with 119 announced bids worth $24.9 billion; telecommunications companies are not far behind, with 31 proposed transactions valued at $23.5 billion, followed by business-services sector, where $8.4 billion hostile bid by Computer Associates for Computer Sciences Corp drove total up to $13.5 billion; graphs; drawing (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mark J. Green, New York City's Public Advocate, moved to stake out ground in the United States Senate race yesterday, decrying abuses by health maintenance organizations and advocating a hefty $1.50-per-pack increase in cigarette taxes to help discourage teen-agers from smoking. In what he described as the first of six major policy speeches, Mr. Green also endorsed a plan that would provide state and federally financed medical coverage for uninsured children and expectant mothers.

headline.main: Green States Policy, and It Is on Health Care

docs.abstract: NYC Public Advocate Mark J Green, in policy speech related to his candidacy for US Senate, decries abuses by health maintenance organizations and advocates hefty $1.50 per pack increase in cigarette taxes to help discourage teenagers from smoking; says he also endorses plan that would provide state and federally financed medical coverage for uninsured children and expectant mothers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After eight years of working in a nursing home, Alaine Dougherty was no stranger to death. When terminal cancer of the esophagus was diagnosed in her mother last April, she knew precisely what she wanted -- or, rather, did not want: ''I didn't want my mom to suffer, and I didn't want all the craziness.'' Despite Mrs. Dougherty's wishes for her mother, Marilyn Snyder's final months were filled with confusion and pain. She was shuttled from one specialist to another: a surgeon, an oncologist, a radiologist, a cardiologist, a gastroenterologist. She was frightened and weak, and when she stopped eating, six weeks before she died in July, her son and daughter knew the end was near.

headline.main: As Life Ebbs, So Does Time To Elect Comforts of Hospice

docs.abstract: Experts say dying patients often get hospice care, which focuses on their comfort and spiritual needs, too late to take advantage of it, sometimes just days or hours before death; note Medicare and most other health insurers pay for hospice care only for last six months of life, time period that is often difficult to predict, and require that patients give up aggressive treatment to prolong life; photos (M)
